title: One-Quasiparticle Bands in Neutron-Rich W-187
abstract: Modest spin states in neutron-rich W-187 have been populated by using a W-186(O-18,O-17) one-neutron transfer reaction. Negative-parity bands previously known are extended to higher spin, and two positive-parity bands are newly identified. Configurations based on nu i(13/2) orbitals are assigned to these bands from an analysis of the level energy systematics as well as the g factors derived from in-band branching ratios.

Modest spin states in neutron-rich W-187 have been populated by using a W-186(O-18,O-17) one-neutron transfer reaction. Negative-parity bands previously known are extended to higher spin, and two positive-parity bands are newly identified. Configurations based on nu i(13/2) orbitals are assigned to these bands from an analysis of the level energy systematics as well as the g factors derived from in-band branching ratios.

fullText:
PHYSICAL REVIEW C 77, 047303 (2008)
One-quasiparticle bands in neutron-rich 187W
T. Shizuma (),1 T. Ishii (),2 H. Makii (),2 T. Hayakawa (),1
M. Matsuda (),3 S. Shigematsu (),4 E. Ideguchi (),5 Y. Zheng (),5
M. Liu (),5 T. Morikawa (),6 and M. Oi ()7
1Kansai Photon Science Institute, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kizugawa, Kyoto 619-0215, Japan
2Advanced Science Research Center, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Tokai, Ibaraki 319-1195, Japan
3Department of Research Reactor and Tandem Accelerator, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Tokai, Ibaraki 319-1195, Japan
4Department of Energy Sciences, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Yokohama 226-8502, Japan
5Center for Nuclear Study, University of Tokyo, Wako, Saitama 351-0198, Japan
6Department of Physics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka 812-8581, Japan
7Department of Physics, University of Surrey, Guildford, GU2 7XH, United Kingdom
(Received 7 January 2008; published 24 April 2008)
Modest spin states in neutron-rich 187W have been populated by using a 186W(18O,17O) one-neutron transfer
reaction. Negative-parity bands previously known are extended to higher spin, and two positive-parity bands are
newly identified. Configurations based on ν i13/2 orbitals are assigned to these bands from an analysis of the level
energy systematics as well as the g factors derived from in-band branching ratios.
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevC.77.047303 PACS number(s): 23.20.Lv, 25.70.Hi, 27.70.+q
The deformed nucleus 187W is located on the neutron-rich
side of the nuclear valley of stability and therefore it is difficult
to study its near-yrast structure owing to lack of a suitable
reaction mechanism. Low-lying levels in 187W are known
from neutron capture [1–3] and (d, p) transfer reaction studies
[3–6]. In addition, the Kπ = 11/2+, T1/2 = 1.55 µs isomer at
411 keV has been identified in our previous study by using a
deep inelastic reaction [7]. In the present work, we employed
an in-beam γ -ray spectroscopic method to investigate higher
spin states of 187W populated in an 18O-induced one-neutron
transfer reaction. This type of experimental technique is effec-
tive for the investigation of near-yrast structure in moderately
neutron rich nuclei [8–13].
The experiment was carried out at the tandem accelerator
facility, JAEA, Tokai [14]. Excited states of 187W were
populated by a one-neutron transfer reaction of 186W(18O,17O).
A self-supporting target of 186W enriched to 98.2% was
bombarded by an 180-MeV 18O beam. The target was made of
two stacked 450 µg/cm2 metallic foils, which are thick enough
to stop target-like nuclei inside the target. Scattered light
ions were detected by four sets of surface-barrier Si E-E
detectors. The γ rays emitted from the residual nuclei were
measured by seven HP-Ge detectors in coincidence with the
outgoing ions. Four of these detectors with relative efficiency
of 60% were arranged symmetrically in a plane perpendicular
to the beam axis at a distance of 6 cm from the target. Two
of these four Ge detectors and two of the Si E-E detectors
were placed in a horizontal plane including the beam axis,
while the other two Ge detectors and two Si E-E detectors
were in a vertical plane. This setup allows us to extract γ -ray
anisotropies for determination of transition multipole orders.
The remaining three Ge detectors with relative efficiency of
30–40% were installed between the four Ge detectors. The
energy and efficiency calibration of the Ge detectors was made
by using standard γ -ray sources of 133Ba and 152Eu. The details
of the experimental setup are described in Ref. [12].
An E-E plot for outgoing ions measured by the Si
detectors is shown in Fig. 1. The ions are clearly separated by
mass and atomic numbers. The energies of ions are calibrated
by assuming that the most intense peak in the E-E plot
corresponds to elastically scattered events of 18O ions entering
at the center of the each Si detector. The dashed line in Fig. 1
represents calculated energy losses for 17O. Figure 2 shows
γ -ray energy spectra gated on 17O ions with the different
kinetic energy windows shown in Fig. 1. In Figs. 2(a) and 2(b),
γ -ray peaks from 187W and 186W, respectively, are observed.
The 186W nucleus can be produced by one-neutron evaporation
from 187W, when the compound-like 187W formed in the
one-neutron transfer reaction is excited above the neutron
separation energy of 5.5 MeV. Thus, the higher energy 17O
gate is used for the present analysis.
Figure 3 shows a level scheme for 187W deduced from the
present experimental data. The spin and parity assignments
of the levels are based on γ -ray feeding pattern as well as
γ -ray anisotropy [8,9] with respect to the reaction plane.
Table I summarizes energies and relative intensities of γ -ray
transitions observed in 187W. The intensities are extracted
FIG. 1. E-E plot for ions measured by the Si detectors. The
dashed line shows calculated energy losses for 17O. The enclosed
areas represent gate windows with kinetic energies of (a) 166–
171 MeV and (b) 160–165 MeV; see Fig. 2.

FIG. 2. γ -ray energy spectra gated on 17O ions with kinetic
energies of (a) 166–171 MeV and (b) 160–165 MeV, corresponding
to the gate windows (a) and (b) shown in Fig. 1. The γ rays assigned
to (a) 187W and (b) 186W are labeled in units of keV.
from γ -γ coincidence data. Low-lying levels of this nucleus
have been studied via neutron capture [1–3], (d, p) transfer
reactions [3–6], and deep-inelastic reactions [7]. The ground-
state band, based on the 3/2−[512] Nilsson configuration, was
previously identified up to a spin and parity of Iπ = 9/2−
[1,3]. The present data extend this band up to Iπ = (21/2−)
with firm assignments made up to Iπ = 15/2−. The 1/2−[510]
band was known earlier up to an Iπ = 9/2− level at 599 keV
[3]. In the present work the band members up to Iπ = (19/2−)
have been identified. The measured excitation energy of the
Iπ = 9/2− state at 613 keV is different from the previous
assignment. In the (d, p) transfer reaction [3], the 599-keV
level was populated with a cross section of 38(5) µb, which
was larger than the expectation for the 9/2− state. As shown
later, the Iπ = 13/2+ state of the 11/2+[615] band is observed
at 597 keV, which is close to 599 keV. This reveals the strong
population of the 599-keV level in the (d, p) reaction owing
to the underlying i13/2 component. Interband transitions to the
3/2−[512] band members indicate a mixing between these
bands.
The 7/2−[503] band is built on an isomeric state with a
half-life of T1/2 = 5 ns at 350 keV. The isomeric bandhead

decays to the Iπ = 5/2− and 7/2− members of the 3/2−[512]
band. The observation of cascade M1(+E2) transitions of 171
and 206 keV, and a corresponding cross-over E2 transition of
377 keV, allows us to place the Iπ = 11/2− band member
at 727 keV instead of the previous tentative placement at
723 keV [3]. Thus, the present data extend this band up
to an Iπ = (15/2−) level at 1229 keV. A level at 639 keV

FIG. 4. Bandhead energies of the positive-parity Nilsson orbitals
in W isotopes. Points at positive (negative) states indicate particle
(hole) states.
decaying to the 7/2−[503] band via a 290-keV transition was
previously assigned as the 5/2−[503] bandhead [3,5], and this
is confirmed in the present work.
The 9/2−[505] bandhead at 364 keV decays to both the
3/2−[512] and 7/2−[503] bands [3,7]. An Iπ = 11/2− level
at 574 keV tentatively placed in this band [3] is confirmed.
The present data extend this band to higher spin states.
A 411-keV isomer with T1/2 = 1.6 µs, based on the
11/2+[615] Nilsson configuration, was observed in our pre-
vious study [7]. This isomer decays to the Iπ = 9/2− level
at 364 keV via a 46-keV transition. In the present work, two
rotational bands are identified above the isomer in the analysis
of delayed coincidences across the isomer. Levels at 597, 816,
1055, and 1312 keV form a strongly coupled rotational band
built on the isomer itself. Three γ -ray transitions of 201, 388,
and 569 keV link a newly observed structure built on a 798-keV
state to the low-lying members of the 11/2+[615] band. The
γ -ray anisotropy data for the 388- and 569-keV transitions
are consistent with the assignments of I = (9/2 or 11/2) and
(11/2 or 13/2) for the 798- and 978-keV levels, respectively.
Since these levels decay only to the 11/2+[615] band, the
Kπ = 9/2+ assignment is preferred for this newly observed
band.
The 9/2+[624] and 11/2+[615] orbitals are known for
the lighter W isotopes of 181W, 183W and 185W [15]. In
Fig. 4 excitation energies for these orbitals are compared
with the corresponding levels in 187W. The 798-keV level
in 187W lies on the systematics for the 9/2+[624] orbitals.
The M1 transition energies of 180, 227, and 245 keV in the
Kπ = 9/2+ band are also consistent with the systematics of
Kπ = 9/2+[624] bands in the region [15] [i.e., increasing the
M1 transition energy for heavier (less-deformed) W isotopes].
To confirm the Nilsson configuration, in-band branching
ratios are examined. Experimental |gK − gR| values are
evaluated with the rotational model expressions [16]. The
quadrupole moment of Q0 = 6.8 e b are chosen as the average

of the values for 183W [17] and 185Ta [18]. Table II compares
the experimental and calculated gK factors for the bands
observed in 187W. For each band, the experimentally derived
gK factors agree, within the uncertainties, with the calculated
values for the proposed one-quasiparticle configurations. The
results support the 9/2+[624] and 11/2+[615] assignment for
the newly observed bands built above the isomer.
A self-consistent Hartree-Fock-Bogoliubov cranking cal-
culation of the type described in Ref. [19] has been performed
for the Kπ = 3/2− band in 187W. The spherical Nilsson
Hamiltonian was chosen for the one-body part in the cranking
Hamiltonian and the P + Q.Q force for the two-body inter-
action. The model space consists of two-plus-two major shells
both for protons (N = 4 and 5) and neutrons (N = 5 and 6).
The result of the present calculation indicates an almost
constant deformation of β ∼ 0.20 for the states up to Iπ =
21/2−. In contrast, the triaxial deformation gradually evolves,
as the total angular momentum increases, from γ = 0.6◦ at
Iπ = 3/2− to γ = 14◦ at Iπ = 21/2−. This is consistent with
the results obtained in our previous studies for even-even
W isotopes [12]. Slightly triaxial deformation (γ = 6.6◦) is
predicted at Iπ = 10+ for the ground-state band in 188W. Note
that the present γ parametrization follows the Hill-Wheeler
definition [20], which has the opposite sign to that of the Lund
convention.
In summary, the near-yrast states of neutron-rich 187W have
been populated by using an 18O-induced one-neutron transfer
reaction. Two positive-parity bands are identified and assigned
ν i13/2 Nilsson configuration. The result of a self-consistent
cranking calculation implies that the ground-state band of 187W
maintains near axially symmetric shapes |γ | <∼ 15◦ up to Iπ =
21/2−.
We thank G. Sletten for the preparation of the 186W target
and the staff of the JAEA tandem accelerator facility for
providing the 18O beam.
